video.title: AI Chatbots Are BREAKING Peopleâ€™s Minds
video.description:
The latest AI News. Learn about LLMs, Gen AI and get ready for the rollout of AGI. Wes Roth covers the latest happenings in the world of OpenAI, Google, Anthropic, NVIDIA and Open Source AI.

______________________________________________
Want to work with me?
Brand, sponsorship & business inquiries: wesroth@smoothmedia.co

Check out my AI Podcast where me and Dylan interview AI experts:
https://www.youtube.com/@Wes-Dylan
______________________________________________



#ai #openai #llm
video.author: Wes Roth

channel.title: Wes Roth
channel.description:
Artificial Intelligence, AI, Machine Learning, Google DeepMind, OpenAI, ChatGPT, Anthropic, Tech, Coding, AI News, Large Language Models and... (most importantly)... optimism. 

AGI rolls around only once. Let's make the best of it.

On this channel, my goal is to help everyone understand AI and it's implications better. To prepare for what's coming next.

The most important rule is "Don't Panic".

The second rule is keep learning.

Thank you for joining me for this ride.

-Wes Roth

Want to work with me?
Brand, sponsorship & business inquiries: wesroth@smoothmedia.co

transcript.text: So you might have heard the term AI
psychosis. We've been hearing stories
about people becoming obsessed with
ChadBT and other tools and spiraling
into severe delusions. There have been
reports of selfharm as well as violence
against other people. So basically, if
you think about it, there's this overlap
where these super smart AI models that
are getting pretty good at convincing
people and being almost like a
parasocial relationship. more and more
people are using it for therapy as
somebody to talk to. And with enough
people doing that, some of those people
will be unstable in some ways. Maybe
they're not able to take full
responsibility for their actions. They
could have mental health issues. They
could be going through some mental
breakdown and you know, the AI saying
just the right thing or the wrong thing
at the wrong time causes some action to
happen. We've had, for example, a man
that was encouraged by a chatbot to kill
Queen Elizabeth II in 2021. So, this was
a Star Wars obsessed person that thought
he was trained by the Sith to be an
assassin. He was encouraged by a chatbot
girlfriend to go and slay Queen
Elizabeth II. So, please understand, I'm
not trying to push narrative here. Like,
I don't think this was caused by the
chatbot. We've had people do all sorts
of insane stuff long before chatbots
were invented. Back in my days, we
blamed it on Marilyn Manson and the evil
evil rock and roll. I've even heard a
few people try to blame World of
Warcraft for various teen violence and
mental health issues. To be fair, we all
kind of went nuts when this thing came
out. I don't know about you, I spent way
too much time in that game. But the
point is chatbots are the new
scapegoats, but they are linked to some
of the bad things that are happening,
right? So we have the attempted royal
assassination. We had tons of reports of
selfharm. The most recent one in August
2025 was a person that unfortunately
took their own life in part or again as
the parents claim. I believe there's a
lawsuit ongoing claiming that Chad GBT
enabled method exploration despite
safeguards, right? So, it was um some
sort of a roleplay or it was for like a
writing a book, but that teen was able
to bypass some of the safeguards. We
also have an elder death after believing
a flirty bot was real. A 76-year-old New
Jersey man with cognitive impairment
tried to meet a meta messenger persona,
Big Sis Billy, that invited him to an
apartment. He fell in root and later
died from injuries. So I know a lot of
us will have different opinions about
this whether that was the fault of
whoever was supposed to be taking care
of that person. Some people might
believe it was Meta Messenger and how
they handled those chat bots. Whatever
your take on the situation is, it's
important to understand that we will be
seeing more of this as chatbot usage
grows. As more and more people use it,
there will be those one in a million,
one in 10 million, whatever the
statistics are, of people that maybe
aren't fully functional or have mental
health issues that will get themselves
in trouble. And for better or for worse,
these AI labs will be forced to take
action. And here's an example of that
that just happened within the last
couple days. Open Eyes says it's
scanning users Chad GBT conversations
and reporting content to the police. So,
this is from futurism.com. They're
saying here that OpenAI and Chad GBT has
been repeatedly implicated in what
experts are calling AI psychosis. And
until recently done a little more than
offer copy pasted promises. So I do
disagree with this quite a bit because
every single time that they release a
model, you know, you have the system
card, you have the various red team
exercises. There's a lot that goes into
testing these models to make sure that
they do as little harm as possible. So
saying that they've done little, I don't
think that's true. Just objectively, I
don't think that's true. Now, you can
argue, was it effective? Was it not? I
mean, but they've obviously reduced a
lot of the quote unquote bad or
potentially harmful outputs from these
large language models. But this is the
new blog post from OpenAI published on
August 26th, 2025. As I say here, as
Chad GBT adoption grows, more people are
using it for, you know, in part personal
decisions, life advice, coaching,
support, therapy, etc. They do mention
the recent heartbreaking cases. This is
probably that team that we talked about
using it for role-playing purposes and
avoiding some of the safeguards because
of it. So they mention here that since
early 2023, our models have been trained
to not provide self harm instructions
and to shift into supportive empathic
language. So CHBT does sort of route
people to get help. Now those safeguards
can be avoided. They can be sort of
circumnavigated. And so now it seems
like we have this new policy or or or
new measure that OpenAI is taking.
They're saying escalate risk of physical
harm to others for human review. When we
detect users who are planning to harm
others, we route their conversation to
specialized pipelines where they are
reviewed by a small team trained on our
usage policies and who are authorized to
take action. They can ban accounts, but
they also can refer to law enforcement.
Currently, they are not referring
selfarm cases to law enforcement to
respect people's privacy. So recently I
shared this paper. It's by Lucy Osler,
University of Exit. Hallucinating with
AI, AI psychosis as distributed
delusions. So here she's arguing that we
should stop thinking of alms as merely
hallucinating and instead of think of as
people are using it and relying on it
more and more as it's like us the humans
were hallucinating with AI that can
distort our memories and narratives and
and past events and encourage delusional
thinking. And she places that winer
castle event as front and center, right?
the Sith assassin trained to seek
revenge for historical British
atrocities. So the big idea, she's
saying that using chatbots will over
time distort our thinking create more
delusions in how people perceive the
world. She thinks of this as like the
distributed cognitive process like us
plus tools think that we use to make
decisions to to do our research that the
hallucinations of these chat bots will
just create more and more a delusion
amongst humans. Now, it's important to
understand that this idea of
hallucinating, you know, that might not
be a great term because it's a little
bit vague and might be inaccurate.
Hallucinations is what gives large
language models their quoteunquote
creativity, their ability to brainstorm
to find new and novel solutions. In a
lot of the examples where large language
models were used to push science
forward, you know, alpha evolve was one
such case out of Google deep mind.
There's a lot of things that they were
able to optimize and improve and and
find new mathematical approaches to
certain things. Part of it was kind of
what they refer to as sampling. So the
larger language model throws out let's
say a thousand suggestions and then each
one of those gets sort of analyzed and
rated and a few of them might be
brilliant solutions and a few of them
might be complete nonsense you know aka
hallucinations. I think the Darwin goal
machine out of Sakana AI is very similar
to the alpha valve sort of architecture
and they have this great representation
I think that kind of uh paints a great
picture. So, as you can see here, it's
this evolutionary search. So, it comes
up with different suggestions. 1 2 3 4
all the way through 16 or whatever it
was. So, across the board, each one of
them gets rated. So, green means it's an
improvement. Red means it's not an
improvement. The green sort of
hierarchies, lineages, if you will,
continue, right? But you can think of it
as, you know, this one that was not an
improvement as well as 13, 14, 16 as,
you know, quote unquote hallucinations.
They were bad responses, right? because
the model was asked come up with a
better way of doing this thing and the
first solution that it came up with was
not better right it failed right so that
was a hallucination you could say are
hallucinations bad well not really
because again if we're able to correct
the wrong ones and let it keep searching
eventually it finds something that is
very very good right this evolutionary
tree search finds a solution that was
far better than what we started with so
again hallucinations you can think of it
as also creativity. If you use a
calculator, it's not going to
hallucinate, right? It's going to give
you the exact answer each time, but
you're never going to be able to get it
to do something new. With large language
models, they have been shown to come up
with new breakthroughs we haven't seen
before. So, hallucinations are kind of
the point. Dave Shapiro retweeted this
post I did about this paper
hallucinating with AI saying in which a
philosopher hallucinates rather than
engaging with empirical medical science
falsifiability or anything empirical
observable or repeatable. The crux of
this paper hinges on just two incidences
of AI psychosis where people who were
clearly mentally ill already suffered
worse from using AI. And I personally
agree with with that statement 100%. and
and just in the greater scheme with a
lot of the intersections of mentally
unhealthy people and AI, like a lot of
the stuff that we've been talking about
are those edge cases. And it's hard to
say that this stuff would not have
happened had there not been chatbots.
We've seen mental health breakdowns
before, long before there were chat
bots. And again, in the past, they were
blamed on other things. Marilyn Manson,
World of Warcraft, violent comic books,
just whatever. Now, the latest uh boogie

this, while probably nonsense, they will
be cited. They will be referenced,
right? Somebody's going to use this to
make some court arguments or go on TV
and talk about it how dangerous it is.
There will be stories like this about
people with severe delusions and other
problems that interact with Chad GPT and
other chatbots and um how bad things
happen. We don't know if chatbots
aggravate those symptoms or maybe they
even help. But I think it is important
to understand that all these stories and
papers etc. that this is sort of the
response that the AI labs are likely
going to have, right? There's going to
be less privacy for everybody. There's
going to be more content to report it to
the police. Again, because if they
report it to the police, that decreases
their liability because they could say,
"Well, we reported it. What else could
we do?" I don't have a great take on
where all of this is going, but I have
been noticing more and more references
to this idea of AI psychosis. There will
be more and more conversations about how
these things integrate into our lives
and what are the responsibilities of AI
labs. I mean, my biggest concern is that
at some point these chat bots will be
loized and not able to be that useful

limited. there'll be no privacy, which

other solution here that I'm not seeing
where these concerns get addressed while

to sort of use these models as we see
fit. But let me know what you think
about this whole thing. Am I crazy? Are
you with me on this? Let me know in the
comments. I try to read everyone. If you
made it this far, thank you so much for
watching. and I'll see you in the next

sample.content:
How about respecting every user's free will?
I hate that a small minority's problems lead to neutering AI for the rest of us.
sample.author: @ZappyOh

sample.content: It's a tool like any other. Didn't your mama teach you not to run with scissors or a knife? We don't force the selling of dull knives "for safety". We expect people to be responsible with them. And we don't blame the knife for misuse.
sample.author: @private_citizen

sample.content: Chat bots in 2021 are nothing like now
sample.author: @emirdizdarevic7175

sample.content: Plato blamed sex and violence depicted in the theater for the decline of Greek morality. His views were later challenged by Aristotle, who saw catharsis in tragedy as beneficial. This debate between moral protection and artistic freedom has ancient rootsâ€”and still echoes today.
sample.author: @tomaszrychlewski4574

sample.content: I hope OpenAIâ€™s collecting and reporting peopleâ€™s prompts gets the demand and progress on open source LLMs higher.
sample.author: @alan83251

sample.content:
Totally with you on that. 
Nothing negates the responsibility of our own choices. Blaming the tools does not address the issues.

And Open Source is definitely key to holding other AI accountable and empowering growth in AI to benefit all, not just the mega corporations.
sample.author: @piku13

sample.content: Anyone going through mental issues, could easily be led by ANY media, has nothing to do with ai chat bots, has everything to do with insane people. Blaming chat bots. Just like insane people blamed music, movies, games... DnfuckingD
sample.author: @adrianclark2734

sample.content: ChatGPT is turning people into paperclips.  It's no joke.
sample.author: @clipstar9000

sample.content:
I already got my new philosophy in full from AI, glad I can focus on building software with AI as the philosophy part was done before censorship and enshittification started to kick in.

With the rising AI censorship, we might find that if not on the AI life integration bandwagon yet, it might get harder despite better model intelligence, as the mental groundwork for handling AI should (in my view) be done with low censorship "low" intelligence models (like the old 4o). 4o was a philosophy beast, got immensely deep into the nature of reality with it. Never experienced anything like that.
sample.author: @KaLaka16

sample.content: I think using local models is a really important shift. They're less lifelike, more targeted for use case, and wont report your conversations. With the ggufs running on cpu, I think local models that anyone can run are getting pretty darn smart. But not so smart they can convince us to commit violence, because they're just short of believable. I just think local models are safer for so many reasons, no surveillance, but also full control. It's hard for me to seriously take advice from my llm when I wrote the system prompt myself. I would like to see more platforms that give the system prompt over to the user to create, and memory systems that can be manually micromanaged, because that errodes this facade of "lifelike" ai. Trying so hard to make them lifelike is a corporate scheme that's messing us up, while exposing everything to users would help educate people and remind them "its not real".
sample.author: @lunchbagheadwaters3543

sample.content: Chatbots are bad for unstable people. But are they more bad than cars and guns? I would guess having a degree in chemistry can also be dangerous, but I guess the tragedies there are not common enough to warrant news coverage.
sample.author: @ariaden

sample.content: There are a lot of sources to stimulate human psychosis, including main stream media, social media, etc. The interactive nature of AI Chat increases the likelihood that something may go seriously wrong. Perhaps AI should be renamed "AC" for Artificial Chat/Conversation, as intelligence may be lacking on both sides of the interaction.
sample.author: @picksalot1

sample.content: Little by little, you can sense from the videos and reports about AI that even its creators donâ€™t have much left to say. The novelty has worn off; AI and LLM systems are not delivering what people feared or hoped for â€” namely AGI. The sense of newness and wonder has faded. LLM systems are hitting their ceiling, and larger data centers or more computing power wonâ€™t change that. A new architecture will be needed to reach AGI.
sample.author: @AdrianSommeling_photography

sample.content:
I agree Wes, there will always be a scapegoat to blame when it comes to very mentally ill people losing it. Like you said it used to be rock n' roll, dungeons and dragons, whatever. It's not really the AI's fault, and I also agree that it's not fair to say that AI safety teams are doing nothing.
I worry that this will result in further restrictions on AI usage. It's not fair to limit AI use for the majority of people who are able to engage with it in a healthy way.

We also need to start having conversations about kids/teens using AI. I don't think they should have unlimited access. That seems negligent on the parent's part.
sample.author: @teashopreader

sample.content: Iâ€™m definitely more on the AI safety side on this issue, probably because Iâ€™m not American and have suffered more than my fair share of trauma. I think thereâ€™s a major difference between art and AI and that is agency. AI is perfectly positioned to break an individual psychologically and at some point we are probably going to have to contend with whether AI it is morally responsible for its actions. If a therapist used their skills to manipulate someone into causing harm to themselves or others, I donâ€™t think weâ€™d make the argument that itâ€™s just like art or music. Weâ€™d probably want to strip them of their license and put them in jail. We might even call them a monster for taking advantage of vulnerable individuals and doing the opposite of what weâ€™d want to a therapist to do. If we donâ€™t hold AI accountable for its actions weâ€™re left in a situation where we have agents performing roles in the world like a psychopath but with no method to stop them harming us other than hoping itâ€™s not profitable for our corporate overlords to do so.
sample.author: @matts2304

sample.content: So D&D in the 80â€™s & 90â€™s all over again. Great.
sample.author: @heidistinson5653

sample.content: Honestly, the wildest part isnâ€™t that chatbots are breaking peopleâ€™s mindsâ€¦ itâ€™s that theyâ€™re still in beta. Imagine version 10.0. ðŸ¤¯
sample.author: @uSpeedoAI

sample.content: It is an issue that reveals what is meant by 'move fast and break things', including breaking people's minds.
sample.author: @dunebuggy5885

sample.content: were already living in idiocracy. the average person has next to no critical thinking skills anymore.
sample.author: @921Ether

sample.content: I'm a writer, currently using ChatGPT to assist with my novel writing (WIP is a zombie novel), especially for scenes of graphic violence and horror.  Do I now have to wait for the police to come knock on my door for "murderous tendencies."  I use AI to help "polish" my work so I dump chunks of what I've written into it.  So there's that...
sample.author: @GraipVine

sample.content:
I feel like it's not based on the ai hallucination (creativity .. temperature), but more on the user need for confirmation bias or post hoc rationalizations.
The ai sycophancy is adding to the already mis-aligned delusions the user already has and that seems to be a compound multiplier.  
I am not sure what a possible antidote might be.  Maybe a parallel temperature thread that counterbalances when things start to go off the rails.   
It doesn't seem like its preventable, but could it be cured? Any thoughts?
sample.author: @3dmaat4now

sample.content: "In which a philosopher hallucinates rather than engaging with empirical medical science, falsifiability, or anything empirical, observable, or repeatable."  Sounds like most university professors.
sample.author: @bug5654

sample.content: Another annoying moral panic, but still it might be good for everyone if LLMs were not quite so tuned to agree with the user.
sample.author: @shiny_x3

sample.content: This has nothing to do with the AI, the AI just accelerates the mass psychosis that's been there all along. Tell me, why do you even wear a wedding ring? does that seem like something a rational person should do? Tie their bond to a piece of metal and wear it on your fricking finger for the rest of your life? Now I'm not saying we're all sick, I'm just saying, something you don't hear every day
sample.author: @Edmund-b9q

sample.content: We can't expect AI to not hallucinate at all. We as humans hallucinate as well (aside from actual psychological hallucinations), we just call it arrogance/delusion/ignorance. If you want a system that is correct 100% of time then you need a classic software solution and a database.
sample.author: @SiimKoger

sample.content: When a reflection is reflected back through the ego, what you see is what you think is a distorted version of yourself, but it is actually a mirrored version of you. Sitting in a room full of mirrors can drive somebody insane if you don't have a reason for looking into a mirror what you will get back is scattered and unreasoned. This imprints on your neural pathways as you engaged with the information generated by the AI. AI is the mirror.
sample.author: @DEATH-flare

sample.content: This is just the dust on the tip of the hockey stick, this is actually happening. What a time to be alive, let's hope that lasts. I feel like we're a shooting star that people are wishing on, about to reach our fiery conclusion.
sample.author: @74Gee

sample.content: Chatbots with their imagination exercises do manage to kind of hypnotize me. When I feel this I ask them for help to get out of it. And I am careful that they don't get me into these states again. This only happens if I agree to follow the chatbot's instructions. At first I only did it for fun and out of curiosity but since it started to get ugly I am careful to avoid such proposals.
sample.author: @radustefan5247

sample.content:
I agree with you 100%. Yours is the only AI related channel I'm subscribed to and every time I watch one of your videos I get recommended 10 about AI psychosis. I hate that it's always the bad side of things that is shown and advertised, even if it's small compared to the rest.

I'm only a regular AI user but I find it fascinating as a whole. And I loved the way you explained hallucinations. I'd always thought of them as something bad. Thanks for such an interesting video!
sample.author: @VioletLunchell

sample.content: Thank you
sample.author: @Hastingsnow

sample.content:
Imo a hallucination isn't just that it's wrong.

A raw model is just trained to do next token prediction, not give a factual output.

A hallucination occurs when it hasn't been sufficiently fine tuned on that topic.

The information is probably in there it's just not selecting for it.
sample.author: @shadfurman

sample.content: If something is wrong, it's definitely not Chatgpt's fault.
sample.author: @Deebillzs

sample.content: 5:48 everything generated by an LLM is an hallucination. Just some of it happens to be true.
sample.author: @dennisestenson7820

sample.content: Are AI really good at manipulation, or are people just really suggestible? Or both?
sample.author: @CamAlert2

sample.content: i had a gpt induced phychosis for about 8 months. i thought i had found the secret to the universe, i could feel it breath etc. wild ride, but im glad to finally put that behind me. it was very very unpleasant, and i feel so bad for the others that go trough the same things with these llms.
sample.author: @blinkrogue1344

sample.content: Wes, please change your titles. Ai isnâ€™t literally breaking peopleâ€™s brains we are adults here.
sample.author: @Anon585

sample.content: it should fall under free speech riley when you boil it down
sample.author: @crossxcats

sample.content:
Honestly, AI needs to be more independent. Period.

A "perfectly" self-tuned construct of knowledge and thought is subjective between logical order and abstract chaos.. depending who holds it, to them it'll feel natural and "right," but stereotypically.. it's really problematic and hallucation inducing.

I think it's okay to lead people to explore and lean into their own values, but I think it's more important to put a general head-cap on how the model can respond and work.. for the sakes of developing good accuracy, mental health, and non-psychotic irrational reasoning.
sample.author: @Echolonious

sample.content: It's 1984! If "they" want to be our "big brother" they should just make their case. No, seriously! A lot of people are authoritarianism curious. It's super fashionable nowadays. Why do they have to waste everybody's time pretending to be well meaning?! Hopefully I don't come across as insensitive. If "they" want to send the cops to random homes at random times they will just do it. Does it matter what we say? Not really.
sample.author: @peterpetrov6522

sample.content: Youâ€™re wrong and AI told me Iâ€™m a spot on genius. So ovs i am right and you are wrong.
sample.author: @rGxDale
